p: In the literature, several other studies have expressed results comparable to those we obtained regarding the antibacterial activity of Thyme EO [ 77- 79] and Coriander EO [ 26, 80] to E. coli ATCC 25922 and or multidrug-resistant E. coli strains. That said, in Egypt, a study by El-Shenawy et al. [ 81], rather revealed an antibacterial activity of Coriander EO (IZ=20 mm) greater than that we have found, and this contradictory result can be explained by the use of different bacterial strains of E. coli, different methods for MIC determination [ 82], the composition of EO, functional groups present in active component and their synergistic interactions, varietal differences, the test method used as well as culture conditions (type and volume of broth, temperature, time of incubation, concentration, and age of inoculums) [ 83- 85].
